dialogs.original: [as LUCENTIO]  Sir, this is the house. Please it you that I call?
dialogs.translated: [As LUCENTIO] Sir, this is the house. Do you want me to knock?

dialogs.original: Ay, what else? and but I be deceived,    Signior Baptista may remember me,    Near twenty years ago, in Genoa,    Where we were lodgers at the Pegasus.
dialogs.translated: Yes, of course. Unless I'm mistaken, Sir Baptista might remember me, Sir Vincentio, from when we both stayed at the Pegasus in Genoa nearly twenty years ago.

dialogs.original: [as LUCENTIO]  'Tis well; and hold your own, in any case,With such austerity as 'longeth to a father.
dialogs.translated: [As LUCENTIO] Very good. Now keep playing your part, and act as respectable as a father should.

dialogs.original: I warrant you.
dialogs.translated: I swear I will.

dialogs.original: But, sir, here comes your boy.'Twere good he were schooled.
dialogs.translated: But sir, here comes your boy. He needs to learn his lines.

dialogs.original: [as LUCENTIO]  Fear you not him.Sirrah Biondello,Now do your duty throughly, I advise you.Imagine twere the right Vincentio.
dialogs.translated: [As LUCENTIO] Don't worry about him.Biondello, boy, now play your part well. Imagine this is the real Vincentio.

dialogs.original: Tut, fear not me.
dialogs.translated: Ha, don't worry about me.

dialogs.original: [as LUCENTIO]  But hast thou done thy errand to Baptista?
dialogs.translated: [As LUCENTIO] But have you delivered the message to Baptista?

dialogs.original: I told him that your father was at Venice,And that you looked for him this day in Padua.
dialogs.translated: I told him that your father was in Venice, and that you expected him in Padua today.

dialogs.original: [as LUCENTIO]  Thou'rt a tall fellow. Hold thee that to drink.  Gives money
dialogs.translated: [As LUCENTIO] You're a fine fellow. Here, have a drink on me.

dialogs.original: Here comes Baptista. Set your countenance, sir.
dialogs.translated: Here comes Baptista. Look appropriately serious, sir.

dialogs.original: Signior Baptista, you are happily met.    [To the  MERCHANT  ]   Sir, this is the gentleman I told you of.    I pray you stand good father to me now.    Give me Bianca for my patrimony.
dialogs.translated: Sir Baptista, it's good to see you.

dialogs.original: [as VINCENTIO]   Soft son.    Sir, by your leave, having come to Padua    To gather in some debts, my son Lucentio    Made me acquainted with a weighty cause    Of love between your daughter and himself.    And, for the good report I hear of you    And for the love he beareth to your daughter    And she to him, to stay him not too long,    I am content, in a good fathers care,    To have him matched.   And if you please to like    No worse than I, upon some agreement    Me shall you find ready and willing    With one consent to have her so bestowed,    For curious I cannot be with you,    Signior Baptista, of whom I hear so well.
dialogs.translated: [As VINCENTIO] Quiet, son.Sir, if I mayhaving come to Padua to collect some debts, my son Lucentio made me aware of the deep love between your daughter and himself. Because of the good reports I've heard about you, and for the sake of the love between your daughter and my son, I won't delayI am glad to have him matched. And if you also approve of the marriage, then you'll find me ready and willing to consent to your daughter's betrothal. I won't be fussy about details with you, Sir Baptista, for I respect you.

dialogs.original: Sir, pardon me in what I have to say.    Your plainness and your shortness please me well.    Right true it is your son Lucentio here    Doth love my daughter and she loveth him,    Or both dissemble deeply their affections.    And therefore, if you say no more than this,    That like a father you will deal with him    And pass my daughter a sufficient dower,    The match is made, and all is done.    Your son shall have my daughter with consent.
dialogs.translated: Sir, pardon me for what I have to say. I like your plainness and honesty. It is indeed true that your son Lucentio here loves my daughter, and she loves himunless they're both good at pretending. Therefore, if you have nothing else to say, and agree that you will treat your son as a father should and settle on a sufficient widow's inheritance for my daughter, then the match is made, and all's done. Your son will marry my daughter with my consent.

dialogs.original: [as LUCENTIO]  I thank you, sir. Where then do you know bestWe be affied and such assurance ta'enAs shall with either parts agreement stand?
dialogs.translated: [As LUCENTIO] I thank you, sir. Where is the best place to draw up the necessary papers and settle this matter?

dialogs.original: Not in my house, Lucentio, for you know    Pitchers have ears, and I have many servants.    Besides, old Gremio is heark'ning still,    And happily we might be interrupted.
dialogs.translated: Not in my house, Lucentio, for you know that I have many servants who might eavesdrop, and "little pitchers have big ears," as they say. Besides, old Gremio is always hanging around and listening, so we might be interrupted.

dialogs.original: [as LUCENTIO]   Then at my lodging, an it like you.    There doth my father lie, and there this night    Well pass the business privately and well.    Send for your daughter by your servant here.    My boy shall fetch the scrivener presently.    The worst is this, that at so slender warning    You are like to have a thin and slender pittance.
dialogs.translated: [As LUCENTIO] Then let's go to my lodging, if you'd like. That's where my father is staying, and tonight we can complete our transactions privately there. Send your servant for Bianca. My boy will fetch the notary right away. The only bad thing is that with such short notice, we'll only be able to offer you a small meal.

dialogs.original: It likes me well.   Cambio, hie you home,    And bid Bianca make her ready straight.    And, if you will, tell what hath happenèd:    Lucentios father is arrived in Padua,    And how shes like to be Lucentios wife.
dialogs.translated: That sounds good to me.Cambio, hurry home and tell Bianca to get ready right away. And, if you want to, tell her what has happened: Lucentio's father has come to Padua, and now she's likely to be Lucentio's wife.

dialogs.original: I pray the gods she may, with all my heart!
dialogs.translated: With all my heart I pray to the gods that she will!

dialogs.original: [as LUCENTIO]   Dally not with the gods, but get thee gone.    Signior Baptista, shall I lead the way?    Welcome! One mess is like to be your cheer.    Come, sir, we will better it in Pisa.
dialogs.translated: [As LUCENTIO] Don't worry about the gods. Go on about your business.Signor Baptista, should I lead the way? Welcome! We'll only have one course to feed you, but we'll make up for it in Pisa. Come, sir.

dialogs.original: I follow you.
dialogs.translated: I'll follow you.

dialogs.original: Cambio.
dialogs.translated: Cambio.

dialogs.original: What sayest thou, Biondello?
dialogs.translated: What is it, Biondello?

dialogs.original: You saw my master wink and laugh upon you?
dialogs.translated: Did you see my master winking and laughing at you?

dialogs.original: Biondello, what of that?
dialogs.translated: What about it, Biondello?

dialogs.original: Faith, nothing; but 'has left me here behind to expound the meaning or moral of his signs and tokens.
dialogs.translated: Well, nothing. But he left me behind to explain the meaning of his signs and signals.

dialogs.original: I pray thee, moralize them.
dialogs.translated: Please, explain them.

dialogs.original: Then thus: Baptista is safe, talking with the deceivingfather of a deceitful son.
dialogs.translated: It's like this: Baptista is safely taken care of. He's talking with the pretend father of the pretend son.

dialogs.original: And what of him?
dialogs.translated: And what else?

dialogs.original: His daughter is to be brought by you to the supper.
dialogs.translated: You're to bring his daughter to dinner.

dialogs.original: And then?
dialogs.translated: And then?

dialogs.original: The old priest at Saint Lukes Church is at your command at all hours.
dialogs.translated: The old priest at Saint Luke's Church is at your service at all hours.

dialogs.original: And what of all this?
dialogs.translated: And what of all this?

dialogs.original: I cannot tell, except they are busied about a counterfeit assurance.   Take you assurance of her cum privilegio ad imprimendum solum.   To th' church take the priest, clerk, and some sufficient honest witnesses.    If this be not that you look for, I have no more to say,    But bid Bianca farewell forever and a day.
dialogs.translated: I'm not sure, except that they are busy with some fake marriage contract. Go get your exclusive rights to that girl. Go to the church and take a priest, a clerk, and some honest-enough witnesses. If this isn't what you've been waiting for, then I have nothing more to saybut bid Bianca farewell forever.

dialogs.original: Hearst thou, Biondello?
dialogs.translated: Do you hear, Biondello

dialogs.original: I cannot tarry. I knew a wench married in an afternoon as she went to the garden for parsley to stuff a rabbit,and so may you, sir.   And so adieu, sir.   My master hath appointed me to go to Saint Lukes to bid the priest be ready to come against you come with your appendix.
dialogs.translated: I can't linger. I once knew a girl who was married in the afternoon as she went out to the garden to look for parsley to stuff a rabbit. It may happen to you too, sir. And so farewell, sir. My master instructed me to go to Saint Luke's and tell the priest to be ready in anticipation of your arrival with your better half.

dialogs.original: I may, and will, if she be so contented.    She will be pleased.   Then wherefore should I doubt?    Hap what hap may, Ill roundly go about her.    It shall go hard if Cambio go without her.
dialogs.translated: I may, and I will, if she agrees. She will be pleased. Then why am I doubtful? What will be will be. I'll just be honest and straightforward with her. But it will be hard for "Cambio" if he loses her.
